variant.question:
Area Navigation is a method of navigation that permits aircraft operation on any desired flight path within the limits of the capability of self contained systems
Which of the following systems is such a self contained sytem?

options.text: Inertial Reference System
VOR/DME-system
DME/DME-system
Global Positioning System

variant.question: During loss of GPS signal, the FMS position will

options.text: Deviate from the actual position
Will only show a speed deviation
Have no effect
Will fail the system and cannot be used

variant.question: The most common sensors interfacing a FMS to compute the aircraft position along the flight plan are: - DME - GPS - LOCALIZER - VOR The combination which regroups all of the correct statements is:
The most common sensors interfacing a FMS to compute the aircraft position along the flight plan are: - DME - GPS - LOCALIZER - NDB The combination which regroups all of the correct statements is:

Which of the following data can be found in the navigation database? 
1: SIDs and STARs 2: radio aids 3: optimum flight level 4: company routes5: cruise speeds

options.text: Only 1, 2 and 4.
Only 2, 3 and 4.
Only 2, 3 and 5.

variant.question:
The most common sensors interfacing a FMS to compute the aircraft position along the flight plan are:
1) IRS
2) DME
3) NDB
4) GPS
The combination which regroups all of the correct statements is:

The most common sensors interfacing a FMS to compute the aircraft position along the flight plan are:
1) MLS
2) GPS
3) VOR
4) IRS
The combination which regroups all of the correct statements is:
What is the source of magnetic variation information in a Flight Management System (FMS)?

options.text: Magnetic variation information is stored in each IRS memory; it is applied to the true heading calculated by the respective IRS.
Magnetic variation is calculated by each IRS based on the respective IRS position and the aircraft magnetic heading.
The main directional gyro which is coupled to the magnetic sensor (flux valve) positioned in the wingtip.
The FMS calculates MH and MT from the FMC position.

variant.question: The Flight Management System (FMS) is organised in such a way that the..

options.text: navigation database in the FMC is “read only”, but the pilot is able to add other navigational data.
navigation database in the FMC is valid for one year.
pilot cannot modify the navigation database once it is installed in the FMC.
navigation database in the FMC is created by the pilot.

variant.question: All the last generation aircraft use flight control systems. The Flight Management System (FMS) is the most advanced system; it can be defined as a:

options.text: global 4-D Flight Management System.
global 2-D Flight Management System.
management system optimized in the horizontal plane.
management system optimized in the vertical plane.

variant.question:
The FMC determines and update present aircraft position from the following systems:
1 – GPS  
2 – IRS  
3 – Radio aids  
4 – ACARSThe combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:
The Flight Management System (FMS) master connects to:

options.text: the AP, FD and A/T
the Captain's AP
the FO's instruments
the Captain's instruments

variant.question: On modern passenger aircraft, the navigation data base usually contains

options.text: airport reference data.
obstacle altitudes.
ATC frequencies.
aircraft performance data.

variant.question: The FMC position is

options.text: computer generated from the IRS and radio navigation positions.
the average of the IRS and radio navigation positions.
the average of the IRS positions.
computer generated from the radio navigation positions.

variant.question:
The most common sensors interfacing a FMS to compute the aircraft position along the flight plan are:
 
1. MLS
2. GPS
3. VOR
4. IRS
 
The combination which regroups all of the correct statements is:

Comparing the present position display on the Boeing 737-400 FMC, you note that there is a 10-mile difference between the left IRS and the right IRS positions
This means that

options.text: at least one of the IRS is drifting.
one position has been computer generated from radio nav positions whilst the other is raw IRS.
no special significance - this is normal.
one system is in IRS ONLY NAV operation and the other has the VHF Nav Radios selected to AUTO.

variant.question: The aircraft database of the Flight Management Computer is updated

options.text: only after a software update.
continuously during flight.
manually every month.
automatically after touchdown.

variant.question: The aircraft database of the Flight Management Computer is updated

options.text: after a software update.
manually every month.
continuously during flight.
automatically after touchdown.

variant.question: In the Flight Management Computer (FMC) of the Flight Management System (FMS), data relating to aircraft engine-thrust characteristics are stored in the:

options.text: performance database.
engine database.
scratchpad file.
navigation database.

variant.question: The Flight Management Computer (FMC) position is..

options.text: the computed position based on a number of sources, e.g. IRS, VOR/DME, ILS and GPS.
independent of other navigation sources.
the same as that given on the No. 1 IRS.
the actual position of the aircraft at any point in time.

variant.question:
The FMC determines and update present aircraft position from the following systems:

1 – SATCOM2 – GPS3 – DME4 – IRS
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:
Some of the FMS have a navigation mode called Dead Reckoning mode (DR), computing airspeed, heading, wind data ground speed and time. This mode is:

options.text: a back up navigation mode to compute a FMS position when the other navigation sensors are no longer operating.
a navigation mode used to monitor the FMS position.
an operating mode used to intercept radials To or From a flight plan waypoint.
the normal navigation mode for FMS which do not use Inertial navigation Systems INS to compute the aircraft position.

variant.question: Some of the FMS have a navigation mode called Dead Reckoning mode (DR), computing airspeed, heading, wind data ground speed and time. This mode is:

options.text: a back up navigation mode to compute the FMS position when the other navigation sensors are no longer operating.
the normal navigation mode for FMS which do not use Inertial navigation Systems INS to compute the aircraft position.
an operating mode used to intercept radials To or From a flight plan waypoint.
a navigation mode used to monitor the FMS position.

variant.question: Aircraft position determined by radio navigation in an FMC is most accurate when derived from

options.text: DME / DME.
VOR / ADF.
DME ranges and/or VOR/ADF bearings.
VOR / DME.

variant.question:
The FMC determines and update present aircraft position from the following systems:

1 – LOC2 – DME3 – IRS4 – GPS
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:
How is the radio position determined by the FMC in the B737-400 Electronic Flight Instrument System?

options.text: DME/DME or VOR/DME
VOR/VOR or ADF bearings
DME ranges and/ or VOR/ADF bearings
VOR/DME range and bearing

variant.question: In flight, which navigation receivers are typically used for flight management position updating?

options.text: DME, VOR, LOC, and GPS receivers.
DME, VOR, LOC, and LORAN receivers.
DME, VOR, LOC, and INS receivers.
DME, NDB, and GPS receivers.

variant.question:
The FMS enables to fly an optimum flight profile. For this, the FMC (Flight Management Computer) uses:

1 – flight-crew entered flight plan data2 – data from ADC3 – aircraft position4 – a memorised relief world data base5 – data from the FMC navigation data base.
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:
Concerning the FMS (Flight Management System), the cost index is determined by dividing:

options.text: aircraft operating cost by fuel cost.
aircraft cruise speed by fuel cost.
fuel cost by aircraft operating cost.
fuel cost by aircraft cruise speed.

variant.question: In an aircraft equipped with a twin inertial system, the FMC displayed position

options.text: would be between the mean inertial position and radio fix position.
would be half-way between the mean inertial position and the radio fix position.
would be the same as the primary inertial system position.
would coincide with the mean inertial position.

variant.question: In which of the following situations is the FMC present position of a B737-400 Electronic Flight Instrument System likely to be least accurate?

options.text: At top of descent.
On final approach.
Just after take-off.
At top of climb.

variant.question:
Comparing the radio navigation system and the inertial navigation system
1) the radio position is accurate when in DME range.
2) the radio position may be obtained whatever the position on the Earth.
3) the inertial position may be obtained whatever the position on the Earth.The combination regrouping all the correct statements is
What is the most accurate method used by the FMC in the B737-400 for radio position determination?

options.text: DME/DME or VOR/DME.
VOR/VOR or VOR/ADF bearings.
VOR/DME range and bearing.
DME ranges and/or VOR/ADF bearings.

1 – GPS2 – NDB3 – DME4 – LORAN-C
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:
During a loss of GPS signal, the FMS position...

options.text: May deviate from the actual position.
Will remain stable because GPS is only a secondary sensor for normal.
Will be completely reset.
Will be calculated using the data from the current navigation database.
